S3.T1.caption: Table 1. A summary of differences between the federated SGD and CGD.
S3.T1.table:
Technique Methodology Desired properties
Architecture Model update Model Accuracy Privacy
Federated SGD Plain SGD (Robbins and Monro, 1951; Bottou et al., 2018) All the particip- ants jointly learn one and the same global model. Update the model using the gradient computed on a subset of training samples in each iteration. Theoretically guaranteed convergence (Robbins and Monro, 1951; Bottou et al., 2018). The sharing of local parameters/gradients is subject to model inversion attack (Melis et al., 2019; Fredrikson et al., 2015; Shokri et al., 2017) .
Privacy-preserving SGD via secure aggregation (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Zhang et al., 2020a; Marc et al., 2019; Sharma and Chen, 2019; Liu et al., 2017) As above, since the mechanism guarantees that the computation result from ciphertext is the same from plaintext (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Mohassel and Zhang, 2017). The sharing of one and the same global model (even though the local gradients are protected) is still subject to information leakage (refer to (Nasr et al., 2019) and Section 5).
Privacy-preserving SGD via differential privacy (Abadi et al., 2016b; Song et al., 2013; Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; Dwork et al., 2014; Hu et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2020b) Additive noise (in most cases) affects the model accuracy (Dwork et al., 2014). The privacy cost is accumulated with repeated accesses to the dataset (Abadi et al., 2016b).
Confined Gradient Descent Each participant learns and confines a different global model. The model update in each iteration embraces the information from all the training samples by summing up the local gradients. Theoretically guaranteed convergence with bounded gap to the centralized model. Boosted privacy preservation by eliminating the sharing of the global model.
references:
To better position CGD, we summarize the related studies in the literature in Table 1.
We use federated SGD to represent the SGD or the mini-batch update in the FL, including both the plain SGD in which the local gradient/model is shared in plaintext,
and privacy-preserving SGD via secure aggregation or differential privacy mechanisms. CGD guarantees that each confined model, when CGD converges, is at the neighborhood of the centralized model, retaining the model accuracy (column 5 in Table 1 and proved in Section 4).
It also achieves desired privacy preservation compared to the traditional FL (column 6 in Table 1 and detailed in Section 5).

S5.T2.caption: Table 2. A summary of the exposed information in traditional FL and CGD
references:
In Table 2, we summarize the privacy enhancement from the perspective of adversary’s observation, i.e, the exposed information to the adversary during the optimization.
In traditional FL, the sharing of global model wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k}, even if the local gradients are protected, is still subject to information leakage about the original dataset.
By eliminating the sharing of wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} and letting each participant confine its own wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l}, CGD achieves boosted privacy over traditional privacy-preserving FL.
(1) Compared to secure aggregated FL in which indicative information about original datasets can be observed via the sharing of wksubscript𝑤𝑘w_{k} (Theorem 2), the variation among wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l} in CGD prevents such information from disclosure, and guarantees that only the sum of local gradients is exposed during the optimization (Theorem 1). (2) Compared to differential privacy mechanism in which privacy decays with the increasing training epochs, the variation introduced to each wklsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝑙w_{k}^{l} hides the local gradients throughout the whole training process, and thus retains privacy regardless of the number of training epochs.

S7.T3.caption: Table 3. Performance comparison on MNIST with default settings.
S7.T3.table:
Validation loss Validation accuracy
Centralized 0.081 97.54%
CGD Local training CGD Local training
m=(10×710710\times 7) 0.143 1.283 96.5% 54.39%
m=(100×4910049100\times 49) 0.189 2.076 94.21% 23.53%
m=(1000×11210001121000\times 112) 0.209 2.348 93.74% 11.64%
references:
Figure 4 summarizes the performance with varying number of participants.
In general, CGD stays close to the centralized baseline in both validation loss and accuracy, and as expected, significantly outperforms the local training.
In the worst case of m=(1000×112)𝑚1000112m=(1000\times 112) when CGD contains the greatest number of participants, i.e., each participant owns a small proportion consisting of 606060 samples with 777 features, CGD still achieves 0.2090.2090.209 and 93.74%percent93.7493.74\% in validation loss and accuracy respectively, close to 0.0810.0810.081 and 97.54%percent97.5497.54\% of the centralized baseline. In contrast, the performance of local training declines to 2.3482.3482.348 and 11.64%percent11.6411.64\%. Table 3 lists the detailed performance comparison with both centralized and local trainings, and Table 4 lists the comparison with DP-FL. More results are given with varying number of participants in Appendix C (Figure 9 and Table 8).

Figure 5 and Table 5 summarize our experimental results against centralized training and local training.
The results on the validation loss and accuracy are generally in line with that on the MNIST dataset.
In the worst case of m=(1000×32)𝑚100032m=(1000\times 32), CGD achieves 0.7240.7240.724 and 74.29%percent74.2974.29\% in validation loss and accuracy respectively, which are relatively near to the centralized baseline (0.6750.6750.675 and 75.72%percent75.7275.72\%).
Table 6 summarize the results against DP-FL. In line with the results on MNIST, the accuracy difference to the centralized baseline in CGD is smaller than that in DP-FL.

references:
The results of our first experiment are shown in Figure 6 and the first five columns in Table 7.
In general, as δ𝛿\delta decreases, CGD achieves better performance.
This confirms our expectation: decreasing δ𝛿\delta would reduce the value of ‖𝔼j∈mh(w1l−w1j)‖normsubscript𝔼𝑗superscript𝑚ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑤1𝑗\|\displaystyle\mathop{\mathbb{E}}_{j\in m^{h}}(w_{1}^{l}-w_{1}^{j})\|, such that the confined models are closer to the centralized optimum.
We have not observed significant difference from δ=0.1𝛿0.1\delta=0.1, 0.060.060.06 and 0.010.010.01.
In the case of m=(1000×112)𝑚1000112m=(1000\times 112), the validation accuracy and loss achieve 97.08%percent97.0897.08\% and 0.0960.0960.096 with δ=0.01𝛿0.01\delta=0.01 which outperform 93.74%percent93.7493.74\% and 0.2090.2090.209 in the setting of δ=0.1𝛿0.1\delta=0.1, but both are close to the centralized model whose validation accuracy and loss are 97.61%percent97.6197.61\% and 0.0780.0780.078 respectively.
However, δ𝛿\delta cannot be set too small, in order to maintain numerical stability in neural network (Glorot and Bengio, 2010).
For example, when we lower δ𝛿\delta to 0.0010.0010.001, the performance starts decreasing.

The results of our second experiment are shown in Figure 7 and the last column in Table 7.
When the participants uniformly randomize their δ𝛿\deltas from 0.0010.0010.001 to 0.10.10.1,
the performance of CGD is still comparable with the centralized mode.
For example, with m=(1000×112)𝑚1000112m=(1000\times 112) participants, CGD achieves 95.82%percent95.8295.82\% and 0.1360.1360.136 in the validation accuracy and loss.
This suggests that CGD keeps robust when the δ𝛿\deltas of its participants differ by two orders of magnitude.
